profileText: A Representative and a Senator from Maryland; born in Annapolis, Md., February 27, 1786; attended local private schools and graduated from St. John's College, Annapolis, in 1802; studied law; admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Annapolis, Md.; member, State house of delegates 1811-1815; established and edited the Federal Republican, an extreme Federalist newspaper, in Baltimore, and on June 22, 1812, four days after war was declared, a mob, irritated by his articles denouncing the administration, destroyed the office; when he issued the paper from another building in late July, he was seriously injured by a mob; moved the paper to Georgetown, D.C., where he published it unmolested; moved to Rockville, Md.; elected as a Federalist to the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Congresses and served from March 4, 1813, until his resignation in 1816; unsuccessful candidate in 1816 for election to the State house of delegates; elected as a Federalist to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Robert G. Harper and served from December 20, 1816, until his death on his estate, 'Belmont,' near Elkridge, Howard County, Md., April 23, 1819; interment in the family burial ground.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Hanson, Alexander Contee. Reflections Upon the Late Correspondence between Mr. Secretary Smith, and Francis James Jackson. Baltimore: Privately published, 1810.

researchRecord.name: 1 letter and 2 documents (1793, 1797, 1815) in Greenway collection.
1737-1877, 1900. 2 portfolios and 1 volume. Correspondence relating in part to the burial of General James M. Lingan, accounts, and business papers. Finding aid.
Several land deeds and Hanson's instructions to newly appointed justices of the peace.1 Chancery Court degree of trusteeship issued by Hanson (1802).
